description: Landscape designer Julie Messervy and a group of landscape architects from Toronto's Parks and Recreation Department designed the waterfront's Music Garden in such a way that it actually interprets in nature Bach's First Suite for Unaccompanied Cello. Starting off with the curves and bends of the riverscape, guests make their way through six sections of the garden ending at the Giant Grass Steps, which form a curved amphitheater where performances take place in the summer.

reviews.title: Stunning.
text: I personally loved it here. I thought the attention to detail was really beautiful and it was well worth the 50 min walk from my hotel to get here (lol)

reviews.title: Lovely park inspired by Bach's Cello Suite No. 1
text: This is a small, but beautiful and well-maintained garden right on the waterfront. Yo-Yo Ma collaborated on its design, which was inspired by J.S. Bach's famous Cello Suite No. 1. If you are a musician, you'll enjoy the landscape interpretations of the six movements. Even if you aren't musical, it's still a nice place to visit if you're in the area.

reviews.title: Pleasant but not spectacular
text: This was our destination along the waterfront from downtown and I'm glad there was seating both in the sunshine and in the shade but it was a bit underwhelming compared to other purposeful gardens I've seen.  The terraced area for performances with a view of the CNN tower was the best bit.

reviews.title: Special spot
text: Beautifully designed garden. Recommend for people who are actually interested in local plans and garden design, or a pleasant short walk. This is not a big showy botanical garden-type place. My husband is a passionate gardener and we enjoyed following the planned routes, observing how the flower and plant selections worked together, and how the design of the whole integrated these things.

reviews.title: I expected more
text: It is a small park in front of the harbour where you can sit and relax under the shadow of a tree. However, it is nothing special but you have some chairs, benches and stairs and sadly, lots of annoying bees. No problem if you don't visit it.

reviews.title: Nice, but small and underwhelming
text: Walking along Queen's Quay is great on a nice, not too windy day. If you are there anyway you can take the little curvy paths through the Music Garden in among the vegetation. I have yet to hear the music, maybe it only happens at certain times? The Music garden is only a small part of the attractions along Queen's Quay. I would recommend the area if you like water.

reviews.title: Nice little oasis of calm
text: Nice park on the waterfront with seating and areas inspired by a piece of classical music. Great place to just sit and chill

reviews.title: Pleasant summer visit
text: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Music Garden this past August. Because if the hot sun we chose not to sit on the grass tiers overlooking the band, instead sitting on benches nearby in the shade.  It was still easy to hear the music.  We were expecting classical music as the ads said, so we're a bit disappointed to get South American pop music.  Nevertheless the whole experience was enjoyable.  After the music finished we wandered around the series of small gardens- for a couple of hours--what a delight.  The Music Garden is very easy to reach on public transit.

reviews.title: Stunning garden with a variety of designs based on  Bach's First Suite for Unaccompanied Cello
text: We took our time sitting in each of the six areas, listening to the relevant piece of Bach's First Suite for Unaccompanied Cello on our phone. But even if you have no interest in the music, the park is lovely with curves and bends from flowers through a wooded area to an amphitheater where performances take place in the summer. A beautiful place to relax.

reviews.title: Beautiful!
text: Only a short walk from the city but so tranquil and lovely. A nice spot to sit and chill out! Beautifully done

reviews.title: Go for the different blooming seasons.I do not know how those gardeners do it,but there is always something in bloom fro
text: An experience combining classical music of very high quality,canadian horticulture and venice USA style people all against a backdrop of boats,harbour and various aerial activities.Enjoy!

reviews.title: No Music
text: Perhaps the information given in the booklet was missing details because there was no music as I stroll around the garden. It was not what it was called.

reviews.title: Gem of a garden
text: I had downloaded the Bach Suite No. 1 beforehand and listened to it as I strolled the garden.  I am glad I did because I never found the office for the self-guided tour.  Also, if you are thinking a picnic or snack---be advised there is nothing on the water side near the garden.  Perhaps you can find something nearby.  In spite of those glitches, it is a lovely garden and I found myself smiling as I walked the garden and the adjacent wetlands.

reviews.title: Beautiful gem
text: The peace and quiet and beauty that surrounds this hidden gem is shocking! Recommend it to come and read a book, just relax, watch the boats.

reviews.title: quaint and cute, nice place for a picnic or rest
text: Ok I love gardens of all kinds. this one I had read about in horticulture magazine this spring and wanted to try--planned a whole trip to Toronto for it. Don't do that. If you are in the area and walking along the harbor- sure stop by. its quiet and peaceful and free and takes about 10min to walk through. Well manicured and some very nice photo ops with plants and sculpture and boats on the harbor.

reviews.title: Beautiful
text: Cracking area of be­­­autiful flowers, pl­a­nts, and paths. Do­es­n't take long to exp­lore, but in aut­umn or spring it is actu­ally excell­ent early mornings for birdwa­tching with go­od num­bers of Warbl­ers, Vi­reos and Fly­catchers.

reviews.title: Small but Perfectly Formed
text: A bijou oasis of tranquility can be found at Toronto's Music Garden. Having limited knowledge of classical music I listened to the piece (Bach's Suite No. 1 in G Major for unaccompanied cello) online before visiting; which helped me understand and enjoy the garden. There's a clear plan at the start and an explanation at each section relating garden to music. And they do relate well to each other.
Well maintained, varied and beautifully set out in a peaceful setting beside the water, these gardens are worth visiting in their own right, music or none.

reviews.title: Wrong Music
text: The Toronto music garden is beautifully maintained and a feat of inspired design. This a place that you can walk arou nd and read all of the plaques to learn how the garden designs were inspired or just find a quiet spot and take it all in. Many photo opportunities. However, there is a lot of noise coming from the pier... blaring hip-hop from a party boat is the wrong kind of music for this garden.

reviews.title: Delightful and quiet.
text: Such a lovely little area. It's great to get away from the hustle and bustleof the city for a short while. You could spend as little or as much time here as you want.

reviews.title: A great place to chill out
text: Right on the shores of Lake Ontario is a garden devoted primarily to classical music.  I do not know any other city in the world that had done this.  The park has several small venues for performance, lots of benches for chilling and the atmosphere is relaxed.  A perfect place to take a load off or your feet!

reviews.title: Nice park
text: Very nicely designed little park next to the marine by the waterfront. It's very well maintained and always nice to walk by.

reviews.title: Nice design
text: This garden is having such a nice design. There are classical concerts scheduled during the summer time.

reviews.title: A little peace of heaven
text: Hidden away by the waterfront, a tranquil spot where the hustle and bustle just fades away, if you are lucky enough to be there when there is a concert and you get on e of the few seat its just paradise, a chance to separate away from the stress of today for a few minutes salvation in harmony.

reviews.title: Hidden treasure by the water!
text: This is a lovely hidden spot down by the waterfront and excellent for a picnic or walk.  It's easy to access by public transportation too.

reviews.title: Nice little spot on quieter spot on the Quay!
text: Enjoy local artists on Thursday nights during the summer. Lots of outdoor seating with Music Garden Café, Starbucks and a few good sushi places for grab and go and enjoy while you watch the entertainment. If coming by 509 or 510 streetcar, just get off at Dan Leckie Way.

reviews.title: Music themed botanical garden
text: Very enjoyable. Self guided audio tours available - rent the wands at the marina office for $6.00. There are lots of places to sit and enjoy. They also have live music some afternoons. Plenty of curving paths and manicured gardens. Lots of flowers.

reviews.title: An enjoyable mid-June stroll
text: Last Saturday we went for an enjoyable 30 minute stroll through the Toronto Music Garden along Queen's Quay West. The winding pathways and views of the waterfront and CN Tower were complimented by the lush plantings and colourful floral beds. The cooling breeze from the lake was refreshing on a warm day.

reviews.title: On the waterfront! Not 2km inland.
text: Delightful garden which was a perfect change of pace from our hectic morning. Lovely planting with twisting, turning paths and a musical theme.

reviews.title: Music explorers
text: This is one of the more unusual things to do in the city, and it should be high on the list for visitors to check out if they want to experience something about Toronto other than the normal trappings which can be found in any North American city.  The layout of the garden is maybe a little confusing without looking at the map but the intent is to make people explore to find the music, not to have it handed to them.

reviews.title: Wrong map location
text: Trip advisor map selection sends you to Queen Street instead of Queens Quay.  Kind of important mistake!

reviews.title: Lovely setting by the Harbour
text: Whilst in Toronto we walked along the Harbour to the Music Garden many times. There are lots of places to sit and watch the world go by. It's a really relaxing spot overlooking the boats on the lake and with the CN tower standing tall in view behind. The gardens are very well kept with an abundance of pretty flowers. I would highly recommend a visit to the Music Garden whilst you are in Toronto, it's hard to believe that the City is on your doorstep, but at the same time you have tranquility and beautiful views!

reviews.title: Beautiful!
text: A rather big recreation area at the shore of Lake Ontario, very meticulously kept and maintained, lots of beautiful flowers, lawns and all kinds of green landscapes. Certainly well worth a visit for a relaxing hour in Toronto!

reviews.title: A garden beside the lake.
text: Interestingly shaped paths and plantings. A short walk-around as part of a bigger plan to see the entire lakeshore area. See many private sailboats in the harbour.

reviews.title: Absolutely lovely
text: Difficult to get to if you are walking because of that terrible overpass freeway but the garden is unique and lovely even though it tis true you can smell the palin fuel when the planes take off form Porter Airport.!! but the gardens are so beautifully maintianed by the city and volunteers and there is a real story behind the building of the garden and its charming the little areas they have created in what is a relatively small space beside the moored boats Walk around the old factory at the nd as well so as to view an unusually group of statues. Just lovely.

reviews.title: The Toronto Music Garden down on Queens Quay is a place to sit and relax.
text: Toronto's waterfront is an amazing place to visit during the summer. A real people place.
The Music Garden has it's own enchantment. Listen to Bach's Suite No. 1 in G Major for unaccompanied cello, BWV 1007 corresponds to a different section of the Toronto Music Garden:
If you get tired of walking you can sit down on the many benches at the Music Garden and take in the gardens that you are sitting in, the people walking by or reading.
A super place for a picnic.
Concerts take place in the Toronto Music Garden on most
Thursdays at 7 pm and Sundays at 4 pm, through the summer  and are approximately one hour in length. Bring a blanket and sit on the grass as bench seating is limited.
From June through September is the annual Summer in the Garden music series

reviews.title: Beautiful gardens by the lake
text: Beautiful gardens by the lake. I have loved running and walking through these beautiful gardens, perfect for a relaxing time and nice photos,

reviews.title: Lovely stroll on a summer day
text: These are beautifully kept gardens right by the water and it was a nicer than I thought stroll. The path 'follows' a musical theme, which is rather abstract, but it's nice. There are some great views of the lake, the downtown buildings, and it's a lovely area with well-kept flowers and greenery. When I was visiting I got a lot of great picture and had a nice 30 minutes walking through and doing some people watching.

reviews.title: Meandering paths, plants, metalwork
text: The music is a charming path along Lake Ontario.  In the summer there is mottled shade, cool lake breezes, lovely benches for sitting, and frequent musical performances.  In the winter there are beautiful colors: leaves and bark, and the elaborate metalwork is exposed.

reviews.title: Mesmerizing Garden
text: You will be in for a treat just visiting this place. It is nice, quiet and inviting. Just sit for awhile and enjoy the inner peace you find in this garden. It is amazing. After a hard day at work, take a stroll into this garden and it will be worth the trip. I dare you to visit, you will thoroughly enjoy your stay.

reviews.title: pretty
text: it's one of those places in Toronto that I always manage to kind of accidentally stumble upon, it's quite pretty and the thought that went into it is AMAZING but it's also kind of forgettable to be totally honest. very much "oh. yeha. here."
